_link.title: I can identify alpha decay on a decay series diagram

toLevel2.stem: How does alpha decay appear on a decay series diagram?
options: A diagonal arrow pointing left and down
A vertical arrow pointing straight up
A diagonal arrow pointing right and up

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay is shown as a diagonal arrow pointing left (decreasing atomic number by 2) and down (decreasing mass number by 4).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay appears as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down on a decay series diagram.

toLevel2.stem: By how much does the mass number change during alpha decay?

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay emits an alpha particle (2 protons + 2 neutrons), so the mass number decreases by 4.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. In alpha decay, the mass number decreases by 4 because an alpha particle (mass number 4) is emitted.

toLevel2.stem: By how much does the atomic number change during alpha decay?

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay emits an alpha particle containing 2 protons, so the atomic number decreases by 2.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. In alpha decay, the atomic number decreases by 2 because the alpha particle contains 2 protons.

toLevel2.stem: On a decay series diagram, the x-axis typically shows atomic number and the y-axis shows mass number. Which direction indicates alpha decay?
options: Moving left on the x-axis and down on the y-axis
Moving right on the x-axis and up on the y-axis
Moving only along the x-axis with no y-axis change
Moving only along the y-axis with no x-axis change

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay moves left (atomic number decreases by 2) and down (mass number decreases by 4) on the diagram.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay moves left (Z decreases by 2) and down (A decreases by 4) on a decay series diagram.

toLevel2.stem: When uranium-238 undergoes alpha decay, what is the resulting daughter nucleus?

feedback.correct: Correct! U-238 loses 2 protons (becoming element 90, thorium) and loses 4 mass units, forming Th-234.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. When U-238 undergoes alpha decay, it loses 2 protons (Z: 92→90) and 4 mass units (A: 238→234), forming Th-234.

toLevel2.stem: Alpha decay on a decay series diagram is shown as a horizontal arrow pointing to the right.

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay is shown as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down, not a horizontal arrow to the right.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay appears as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down on decay diagrams, not horizontal to the right.

toLevel2.stem: During alpha decay, both the mass number and atomic number of the nucleus decrease.

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay decreases mass number by 4 and atomic number by 2, as the nucleus loses 2 protons and 2 neutrons.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay does decrease both numbers—mass number by 4 and atomic number by 2.

toLevel3.stem: Why does alpha decay appear as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down on decay series diagrams?
options: Because the nucleus loses 2 protons (moving left) and 4 nucleons total (moving down)
Because alpha particles are deflected diagonally by magnetic fields
Because the energy released travels in a diagonal direction
Because alpha decay only occurs in elements positioned diagonally on the periodic table

feedback.correct: Correct! The arrow represents the changes in atomic number (left by 2) and mass number (down by 4) when an alpha particle is emitted.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The diagonal arrow represents the loss of 2 protons (decreasing Z, moving left) and 4 nucleons (decreasing A, moving down).

toLevel3.stem: On a decay series diagram, an arrow goes from element X to element Y with a change of -2 in atomic number and -4 in mass number. What type of decay does this represent?
options: Alpha decay, because these are the characteristic changes when an alpha particle is emitted
Beta decay, because the atomic number changes
Gamma decay, because energy is released
Neutron emission, because the mass number decreases

feedback.correct: Correct! A decrease of 2 in atomic number and 4 in mass number is the signature of alpha decay (emission of a helium-4 nucleus).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Changes of -2 in atomic number and -4 in mass number specifically identify alpha decay.

toLevel3.stem: Comparing alpha and beta decay on a decay series diagram, how do their arrow directions differ?
options: Alpha decay arrows go diagonally left-down, while beta decay arrows go diagonally right and mostly horizontal
Alpha decay arrows go right, while beta decay arrows go left
Both types of decay have identical arrow directions
Alpha decay arrows go straight up, while beta decay arrows go straight down

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay shows a steep diagonal (left and down) due to changes in both Z and A, while beta decay moves right with little or no change in mass number.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay arrows go diagonally left-down (Z-2, A-4), while beta decay goes diagonally right with mass number unchanged.

toLevel3.stem: If a nucleus at position (Z=88, A=226) undergoes alpha decay, where would the daughter nucleus appear on the decay diagram?

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay reduces atomic number by 2 (88→86) and mass number by 4 (226→222).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay produces a daughter at Z-2 and A-4, so (88,226) becomes (86,222).

toLevel3.stem: Why does alpha decay cause a larger shift on a decay diagram compared to beta decay?
options: Alpha decay changes both atomic number and mass number significantly, while beta decay mainly changes atomic number with no mass change
Alpha particles travel faster than beta particles
Alpha decay releases more gamma radiation than beta decay
Beta decay only occurs in light elements with small atomic numbers

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay changes Z by 2 and A by 4, causing diagonal movement, while beta decay changes Z by 1 with A unchanged, causing mainly horizontal movement.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay produces larger diagram shifts because it changes both Z (by 2) and A (by 4), unlike beta decay which only changes Z by 1.

toLevel3.stem: Looking at a decay series diagram, you see two consecutive arrows: the first goes diagonally left-down, the second goes diagonally right with no vertical change. What decay sequence does this represent?
options: Alpha decay followed by beta decay
Beta decay followed by alpha decay

feedback.correct: Correct! The left-down diagonal indicates alpha decay (Z-2, A-4), and the right-moving arrow with no vertical change indicates beta decay (Z+1, A unchanged).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Left-down diagonal is alpha decay, and right-moving horizontal is beta decay.

feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Alpha decay moves diagonally while beta decay moves mainly horizontally.

toLevel3.stem: The steep diagonal arrow of alpha decay on a diagram reflects the fact that both protons and neutrons are removed from the nucleus.

feedback.correct: Correct! The alpha particle contains 2 protons and 2 neutrons, so its emission changes both the atomic number (horizontal) and mass number (vertical).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The diagonal reflects changes to both Z (from losing protons) and A (from losing protons and neutrons).

toLevel4.stem: A decay series diagram shows a nucleus at (Z=92, A=238). After one decay step, it appears at (Z=90, A=234). What decay occurred and what equation represents it?

feedback.correct: Correct! The changes (Z: 92→90, A: 238→234) match alpha decay, where uranium-238 emits an alpha particle to become thorium-234.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. A change of -2 in Z and -4 in A indicates alpha decay: ²³⁸₉₂U → ²³⁴₉₀Th + ⁴₂He.

toLevel4.stem: On a decay series diagram, you need to plot the alpha decay of radium-226 (Z=88, A=226). At what coordinates should you place the daughter nucleus?

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay reduces Z by 2 (88→86) and A by 4 (226→222), placing radon-222 at (86, 222).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay of Ra-226: Z goes from 88 to 86 (-2), A goes from 226 to 222 (-4).

toLevel4.stem: A student is analyzing a decay series and sees an arrow going from (Z=84, A=218) to (Z=82, A=214). They claim this is beta decay. Is the student correct?
options: No, this is alpha decay because both Z decreased by 2 and A decreased by 4
Yes, this is beta decay because the atomic number decreased
Yes, this is beta decay because the element changed
No, this is gamma decay because energy was released

feedback.correct: Correct! The changes (ΔZ = -2, ΔA = -4) are characteristic of alpha decay, not beta decay.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta decay changes Z by ±1 with no A change. Here, Z changes by -2 and A by -4, which is alpha decay.

toLevel4.stem: Starting at polonium-214 (Z=84, A=214), two consecutive alpha decays occur. Where does the nucleus end up on the decay diagram?

feedback.correct: Correct! Each alpha decay: Z-2 and A-4. After two: Z = 84-4 = 80, A = 214-8 = 206.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Two alpha decays: Z decreases by 4 total (84→80), A decreases by 8 total (214→206).

toLevel4.stem: You are given a blank decay diagram and asked to plot the sequence: Th-232 → Ra-228 → Ac-228. What directions should the two arrows point?
options: First arrow: diagonal left-down (alpha); Second arrow: diagonal right (beta)
First arrow: diagonal right (beta); Second arrow: diagonal left-down (alpha)

feedback.correct: Correct! Th-232 to Ra-228: Z goes 90→88 (-2), A goes 232→228 (-4) = alpha. Ra-228 to Ac-228: Z goes 88→89 (+1), A unchanged = beta.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Th-232 to Ra-228 is alpha (Z-2, A-4), and Ra-228 to Ac-228 is beta (Z+1, A same).

toLevel4.stem: A researcher observes three consecutive diagonal left-down arrows on a decay series diagram starting from uranium-238. What is the resulting nucleus after these three alpha decays?

feedback.correct: Correct! Three alpha decays from U-238: Z = 92-6 = 86, A = 238-12 = 226. Wait, that gives Z=86 (Rn). Let me recalculate: the correct answer depends on the actual U-238 series which includes beta decays.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. After three alpha decays starting from U-238 (Z=92, A=238): Z = 92-6 = 86, A = 238-12 = 226, giving Rn-226. However, the actual decay series path includes beta decays between some alpha decays.

toLevel4.stem: Using a decay series diagram, a student needs to identify all alpha decays in a sequence. They should look for arrows that:
options: Move 2 units left and 4 units down
Move 1 unit right with no vertical change
Stay at the same position (no movement)
Move only vertically with no horizontal change

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay always shows movement of -2 in Z (left) and -4 in A (down) on the diagram.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay is identified by arrows moving 2 units left (ΔZ=-2) and 4 units down (ΔA=-4).

feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Two alpha decays give Z = 92-4 = 88 and A = 238-8 = 230.

toLevel5.stem: Analyzing the uranium-238 decay series diagram, why do multiple alpha decays alternate with beta decays rather than occurring consecutively?
options: After alpha decay reduces the proton count, beta decay is needed to adjust the neutron-to-proton ratio before the nucleus is stable enough for another alpha decay
Government regulations require alternating decay patterns in nuclear waste
Alpha particles physically block other alpha particles from being emitted consecutively
The diagram is drawn incorrectly; all alpha decays should occur first

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay changes the n/p ratio. The daughter nucleus often needs beta decay to reach a more favorable ratio before another alpha decay can occur.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The alternating pattern reflects the nucleus needing to adjust its neutron-to-proton ratio through beta decay after alpha decay changes this ratio.

toLevel5.stem: On a decay series diagram, the uranium-238 series shows 8 alpha decays total. Analyze the total change in atomic number and mass number from start to finish due to alpha decay alone.
options: Atomic number decreases by 16, mass number decreases by 32
Atomic number decreases by 8, mass number decreases by 8
Atomic number decreases by 32, mass number decreases by 16
Atomic number decreases by 10, mass number decreases by 40

feedback.correct: Correct! 8 alpha decays: ΔZ = 8 × (-2) = -16, ΔA = 8 × (-4) = -32. This accounts for part of the total change from U-238 to Pb-206.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Each alpha decay: ΔZ=-2, ΔA=-4. For 8 decays: ΔZ = -16, ΔA = -32.

toLevel5.stem: A student claims that counting only the diagonal left-down arrows on a decay series diagram gives the total number of nucleons lost. Evaluate this claim.
options: The claim is correct because only alpha decay removes nucleons from the nucleus, and each alpha decay removes exactly 4 nucleons
The claim is incorrect because beta decay also removes nucleons
The claim is incorrect because gamma decay removes nucleons too
The claim is correct because all decay types show as diagonal arrows

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta decay converts nucleons but doesn't remove them; gamma decay releases energy without nucleon loss. Only alpha decay (diagonal left-down) removes nucleons.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Only alpha decay removes nucleons (4 per decay). Beta and gamma processes don't remove nucleons from the nucleus.

toLevel5.stem: The thorium-232 decay series shows 6 alpha decays ending at lead-208. Analyze whether the pattern of alpha decays alone could transform thorium-232 directly to lead-208.
options: No, because 6 alpha decays would change Z by 12 (90→78), not reaching lead (Z=82), so beta decays must compensate
Yes, 6 alpha decays exactly transform thorium-232 to lead-208
No, because alpha decays cannot occur in thorium isotopes
Yes, but only if all 6 alpha decays occur simultaneously

feedback.correct: Correct! 6 alpha decays: ΔZ = -12 (90→78, platinum). But lead has Z=82, so beta decays must increase Z by 4 to reach lead.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. 6 alpha decays alone would give Z = 90-12 = 78 (platinum), not Z = 82 (lead). Beta decays are needed to adjust Z.

toLevel5.stem: A textbook shows a decay series diagram where an arrow goes from (Z=86, A=222) diagonally to (Z=84, A=217). Evaluate whether this correctly represents alpha decay.
options: No, this is incorrect because alpha decay should give A=218 (222-4), not A=217
Yes, this correctly represents alpha decay on the diagram
No, this is incorrect because alpha decay should increase the atomic number
Yes, but only for this specific isotope which has unusual decay properties

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay must reduce A by exactly 4. From A=222, the daughter should have A=218, not A=217. The diagram contains an error.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay always reduces mass number by exactly 4. From 222, the correct value would be 218, not 217.

toLevel5.stem: Comparing the U-238 series (8 alpha, 6 beta decays) with the Th-232 series (6 alpha, 4 beta decays), analyze why both end at stable lead isotopes despite different decay patterns.
options: Both series reduce Z to 82 (lead) through combinations of alpha (Z-2) and beta (Z+1) decays that mathematically reach the same stable region
Lead has special properties that stop all radioactive decay regardless of the path taken
The series end at lead only due to coincidence, not physical principles
Both series actually end at different elements, not lead

feedback.correct: Correct! U-238: 92 - 16 + 6 = 82. Th-232: 90 - 12 + 4 = 82. Different combinations of alpha (ΔZ=-2) and beta (ΔZ=+1) decays reach Z=82.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Both reach lead (Z=82) because their combinations of alpha and beta decays produce the same final atomic number.

toLevel5.stem: A researcher proposes using decay series diagrams to identify unknown isotopes by measuring the direction and magnitude of decay arrows. Evaluate the feasibility of this approach.
options: This is feasible because each decay type produces specific, measurable changes in Z and A that can be verified against predicted diagram positions
This is not feasible because decay arrows are impossible to measure in real experiments
This is only feasible for alpha decay but not for beta or gamma processes
This approach cannot work because all decay types produce identical diagram changes

feedback.correct: Correct! By measuring the changes in atomic number and mass number (corresponding to diagram arrow directions), decay types can be identified and daughter nuclei predicted.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Measuring ΔZ and ΔA allows decay type identification (alpha: -2,-4; beta: ±1,0; gamma: 0,0) and daughter nucleus prediction.

toLevel5.stem: On a decay series diagram, some isotopes show branching where both alpha and beta decay are possible from the same parent. Analyze what determines which path predominates.
options: The relative probabilities depend on nuclear energy levels and stability; the decay with higher probability will be more commonly observed
The isotope always chooses alpha decay because it releases more energy
External temperature determines which decay path the nucleus follows
Branching is impossible; each isotope can only undergo one type of decay

feedback.correct: Correct! When branching occurs, each decay mode has a certain probability based on nuclear structure. Both paths appear on diagrams with different branch percentages.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Branching ratios depend on nuclear properties; some nuclei can undergo either alpha or beta decay with different probabilities.
